title: Sometimes it's the little things: A look at Alabama's 'world's smallest' titles
text:
We've bragged before on Alabama's "world's largest titles," such as the Vulcan the largest cast-iron statue; the World's Largest Office Chair in Anniston; and Enterprise's Boll Weevil Monument which is the largest because, well, it's the only statue honoring a cotton-eating bug. Click here to read more.
Today, we're going to celebrate the little things that are important in Alabama: Its "world's smallest" title holders. Some titles are officially recognized, while others are unmeasured claims. Either way, they are lots of fun.
If you know of others, email kkazek@al.com .
World's Smallest City Block, Dothan
A tiny concrete triangle on East Troy Street in downtown Dothan is recognized by the Guinness Book of World Records as the World's Smallest City Block. Click here to read more.
World's Smallest St. Patrick's Day Parade, Enterprise
Each year since 1993, the Enterprise Chamber of Commerce has held what it calls the World's Smallest St. Patrick's Day Parade. What makes it the smallest? It has one participant, a person chosen to be grand marshal and the entire parade. The parade is also fairly short, from the Coffee County Courthouse to the famed Boll Weevil Monument, but it draws a large crowd of onlookers. Click here to read more .
World's Smallest Mardi Gras Parade, University of Alabama
An unusual club at the University of Alabama holds one of the state's strangest parades each year. The Mallet Assembly is sort of like a fraternity for "unconventional thinkers," according to its website. It is a residence for honors students named for its original home, Mallet Hall. Each year since about 1980, members of the Mallet Assembly have set aside Fat Tuesday for what they bill the "World's Smallest Mardi Gras Parade," according to alumnus Chris Luehmann. It features a person chosen as that year's king or queen riding in the back of a truck with a member of the university's Million Dollar Band on either side. The parade moves along a short route on sorority row.
World's Smallest Airport Runway, various locations
Greg Koontz of Ashville is not only a stunt-plane pilot, he is also a comedian. So he combines his talents and offers comic airshows. One of his most popular acts is landing his small plane on what he bills as the "World's Smallest Airport Runway:" the bed of a pickup truck. Yep. At each show, Koontz wows the crowd by landing on a specially rigged truck bed. Click here to read more about Koontz and his air shows.
World's Smallest Man, Wetumpka
Pete Moore, born in Wetumpka in 1932 to a family of nine children, was a circus performer billed as the World's Smallest Man. He had osteogenesis imperfecta . Moore, who was 18 inches tall and weighed 32 pounds, was highly intelligent, according to the website phreeque.com , but was not allowed to attend school for much of his life. He married and had two children, one normal sized and one with the same disorder. Moore died of heart failure in 1984. Click here to read about other Alabama circus performers.
World's Smallest Mysterious Tower of Newport, R.I., Cullman
If you're thinking a mystery tower in Rhode Island sounds like an odd object to replicate in Cullman, Ala., you're right. Really, the miniature tower is part of a much larger "small" thing, the Ave Maria Grotto, billed as "Jerusalem in Miniature." The grotto at St. Bernard's Abbey features tiny replicas of world-famous structures, made from concrete and found objects by a hunchback monk named Brother Joseph Zoettl. In his lifetime, Zoettl built 125 mini structures at the Abbey. It is now open as a tourist attraction.
The grotto includes a miniature Hanging Gardens of Babylon, St. Peter's Basilica, Leaning Tower of Pisa, Egyptian pyramids, and much more. I chose to list the replica of the Mysterious Tower of Newport, R.T., because it is so unusual. While there is likely a smaller replica of the pyramids, it is unlikely you'll find a smaller Mysterious Tower of Newport . So what is it?
It is the stone base of an aging windmill in Newport's Touro Park. The mystery involves its age. Historians have dated it as a mid-17 th century structure built by Gov. Benedict Arnold. However, some speculated it was built several centuries earlier, which would prove explorers came to America before Columbus. The tower has been carbon-dated but speculation about its origins continues. Click here to read about more replicas in Alabama.
World's Smallest Museum, Tuscaloosa
If you're a sixth-grade teacher trying to get students interested in classic authors such as Edgar Allan Poe, what do you do? If you're Tommy Flowers of University Place Middle School in Tuscaloosa, you create the World's Smallest Museum dedicated to Poe and his works â€“ in a closet.
Flowers initially created the tiny museum called Edgar's Closet in 2008 but the school was destroyed by a tornado on April 27, 2011, and many of the collectibles were damaged. Flowers salvaged what he could and, when the school was rebuilt, he reopened Edgar's Closet in his classroom with about 1,000 objects. Flowers said students have become much more interested in the classics. The museum has been recognized as the World's Smallest Museum by the World's Record Association. Recognition from Guinness World Records is pending, he said.
